repnme.cdata!:
Iraq - Emergency School Construction and
            Rehabilitation Project

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Emergency School
            Construction and Rehabilitation Project for Iraq were as
            follows: outcomes were moderately satisfactory, risk to
            development outcome was moderate, Bank performance was
            moderately satisfactory, and Grantee performance was
            moderately satisfactory. Some lessons learned included:
            development progress in conflict-affected environments is
            rarely predictable or linear and cannot be fully mitigated
            through design. In fragile situations where conventional
            supervision missions are not possible a Fiduciary Management
            Agent (FMA) can help provide implementation support. In
            fragile states, the World Bank should always assume low
            institutional capacity and high turnover, and the design of
            emergency projects in conflict affected situations should be
            very simple, manageable in scope, and suitable to context,
            with a primary focus on outputs. An early restructuring may
            be advisable whenever a project implementation is faced with
            major and persistent difficulties that seem to resist all
            attempts to remedy. While the World Development Report (WDR)
            2011 notes that institutional development is a generational
            proposition, emergency responses can successfully develop
            pockets of institutional capacity over the short-term. In
            civil works projects, disbursement mechanisms need to be
            designed in ways that facilitate project implementation and
            that do not expose contractors to cash flow problems.

repnme.cdata!:
Iraq - Emergency School Construction and
            Rehabilitation Project : restructuring

abstracts.cdata!:
The objective of the Emergency School
            Construction and Rehabilitation Project for Iraq is to
            improve conditions of learning of students in primary and
            secondary schools in Iraq through the construction of new
            schools, the extension of existing schools, and the
            rehabilitation of schools in need of urgent repair. The
            reallocation is necessary to make use of the cost savings
            made under the 'works' expenditure category to
            finance training and to cover operational expenses arising
            from the closing date extension of one year, from June 30,
            2012 to June 30, 2013. Previously, the training was funded
            through two expenditure categories: 'consultants'
            services' to finance the cost of the training service
            providers, and 'training' to finance all costs
            related to the participants. To better account for funds
            allocated to training activities, it was agreed to
            reallocate relevant funds from the 'consultants'
            services' category to the 'training'
            category; this will fund all training related costs,
            including costs of trainers, training material, training
            venue, participants' travel, accommodations and per
            diem, as well as the cost of printing and translation as
            follows: category (one): reallocate US$600,000 to category
            (four) and (five), category (two): no change. Category
            (three) reallocates US$489,000 to category (four) and
            (five). Category (four) US$839,000 through adding US$600,000
            from category (one), and US$239,000 from category (three);
            category (five) US$250,000 through adding same from category
            (three); category (four) will finance all training related
            costs; whereby expenditures, inter alia, per diem, travel,
            and visas will not be included in the procurement plan.
